text: Lindsey Graham played political games with federal resources that South Carolina needs. And he just lost. Now, the folks at MCAS Beaufort lose $11 million for a desperately needed fire station. Shameful. When I'm elected, I'll always put SC first.

Let's get this straight: no one *wants* to be on unemployment. You do it because you lost your job and you need to feed your family and pay the rent for a few weeks.  Anyone who says otherwise hasn't spent enough time around real, hard-working South Carolinians.

Our leadership in SC failed us. They took away the resources for us to manage one of the most precious gifts we have - our health. Now, we reap what they sowed.  Time to kick them out, starting with Lindsey Graham.

I'm Jaime Harrison. The son of a single mom from the "corridor of shame," I earned a scholarship to Yale, and then came back home to fight for folks here in South Carolina. I'm running for the United States Senate to bring our state (and country) together.

The COVID-19 outbreak calls for a strong national response, with qualified, competent leadership at the top who listen to medical experts and marshal the full resources of the federal government. Read my plan here.
With your help, we're going to take Lindsey Graham on this November.

We are working *so hard* this weekend to hit our end of quarter fundraising goal (psst donate here üëâüèø https://bit.ly/2NlXPZL)  But, I‚Äôd like to take a break to tell you a little bit more about myself. üè° I was born and raised here in Orangeburg, South Carolina. The son of a teen mom, we didn‚Äôt have much growing up, and my family often struggled to put food on the table. But my grandparents and parents taught me the important stuff: hard work matters. üì´ As a teenager, I got an envelope in the mail that changed my life. With a scholarship (and a lot of student loans) I got an opportunity that kids from Orangeburg don‚Äôt usually get: an education at Yale University. After college, I came back to S.C. and taught 9th grade ‚úèÔ∏èüìö, ran a nonprofit for low income students, worked forJames E. Clyburn, and eventually got a degree from Georgetown Law.  Which brings us to today. Rural hospitals are closing, young people are saddled with huge student loan debt, and poor kids *still* aren‚Äôt getting the opportunities they deserve. And Lindsey Graham isn't fighting for us.  And that's my story. I‚Äôm ready to fight if you are. üí™üèø Together, we‚Äôll stand up for working families, our healthcare, and our children.
